<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.1"><h2><span class="headingNumber">1. </span><span class="head">Introduction</span></h2><p>Achieving consistent encoding within a given community of practice has been a recurrent issue for the TEI Guidelines. The topic is of particular importance for lexical data if we think of the potential wealth of content we could gain from pooling together the information available in the variety of highly structured, historical and contemporary lexical resources. Still, the encoding possibilities offered by the Dictionaries Chapter in the Guidelines are too numerous and too flexible to guarantee sufficient interoperability and a coherent model for searching, visualising or enriching multiple lexical resources.</p><p>Following the spirit of TEI Analytics [Zillig, 2009], developed in the context of the MONK project, <span style="font-weight:bold">TEI Lex-0</span> aims at establishing a baseline encoding and a target format to facilitate the interoperability of heterogeneously encoded lexical resources. This is important both in the context of building lexical infrastructures as such [Ermolaev and Tasovac, 2012] and in the context of developing generic TEI-aware tools such as dictionary viewers and profilers. T</p><p>TEI Lex-0 should not be thought of as a replacement of the Dictionary Chapter in the TEI Guidelines or as the format that must be used for editing or managing individual resources, especially in those projects and/or institutions that already have established workflows based on their own flavors of TEI. TEI Lex-0 should be primarily seen as a format that existing TEI dictionaries can be univocally transformed to in order to be queried, visualised, or mined in a uniform way. At the same time, however, there is no reason why TEI Lex-0 could not or should not be used as a best-practice example in educational settings or as a set of best-practice guidelines for new TEI-based projects, especially considering the fact that in TEI Lex-0 we aimed to stay as aligned as possible with the TEI subset developed in conjunction with the revision of the ISO LMF (Lexical Markup Framework) standard (cf. [Romary, 2015])</p><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.1_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">1.1. </span><span class="head">Context</span></h3><p>Preliminary work for the establishment of TEI Lex-0 started in the Working Group "Retrodigitised Dictionaries" lead by Toma Tasovac and Vera Hildenbrandt as part of the COST Action <a class="link_ref" href="http://www.elexicography.eu">European Network of e-Lexicography</a> (ENeL). Upon the completion of the COST Action, the work on TEI Lex-0 was taken up by the DARIAH Working Group "Lexical Resources" which is co-chaired by Laurent Romary and Toma Tasovac. Currently, the work on TEI Lex-0 is conducted by the DARIAH WG "Lexical Resources" and the H2020-funded <a class="link_ref" href="https://elex.is">European Lexicographic Infrastructure</a> (ELEXIS).</p><p>The above paragraph should be expanded to include a list of meetings we organized, who sponsored them, who attended etc. </p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.1_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">1.2. </span><span class="head">Dictionary model vs. XML serialization</span></h3><p>A fundamental principle that the present enterprise relies on is the nature of the mapping of the physical or “near-physical” (OCR-ed) dictionary contents onto the abstract model of a dictionary structure, and the mapping from said model onto its (in our case) TEI XML serialization. It is important to keep in mind the distinction between the abstract model and its serialization because, as we shall see, the TEI uses the same elements of the abstract model to serve many kinds of text-modelling tasks, and standardly employs ‘features’ or ‘facets’ of these elements (known in the XML world as attributes) to express differences among them. The fact that some elements of the serialization have names closely corresponding to what we can customarily find in the dictionary model is more or less a lucky coincidence. It is not the pattern to be expected. A lexicographer coming from outside of the TEI universe should not necessarily expect his or her customary terms (names of dictionary objects in the dictionary model) to be straightforwardly reflected in the TEI vocabulary names.</p><p>Take, for instance, the TEI element <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a>. Originally, its TEI name came from the word “citation” and this is what the element was used for up to the early days of TEI P5, when it acquired a new, broader function of grouping together pieces of text perceived or broadly treated as “foreign” or additional, together with their (bibliographic, linguistic, or usage-oriented) description. This element is nowadays used as a “container” for citations, dictionary examples, translation equivalents etc. The value of the attribute <span class="att">type</span> is used to further specify the kind of cit-object at hand. In our case, four distinct names of dictionary objects in the abstract dictionary model (namely, “citation”, “example”, “translation” (of quotes) and “translation equivalent” (of words) map onto four distinct element+attribute combinations in the TEI XML serialization (respectively, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> with <span class="att">type</span>="citation", <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> with <span class="att">type</span>="example", and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> with <span class="att">type</span>="translation" or <span class="att">type</span>="translationEquivalent".</p><p>The following example from a bilingual dictionary, shows how one typed element – <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> – can be used to encode different parts of the dictionary structure:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e98" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>horrifier<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>v<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translationEquivalent</span>"
   <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><quote></span>horrify<span class="element"></quote></span>
  <span class="element"></cit></span>
  <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">example</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><quote></span>elle était horrifiée par la dépense<span class="element"></quote></span>
   <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translation</span>" <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><quote></span>she was horrified at the expense<span class="element"></quote></span>
   <span class="element"></cit></span>
  <span class="element"></cit></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div></div>
<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.2"><h2><span class="headingNumber">2. </span><span class="head">Entries and entry-like objects</span></h2><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.2_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">2.1. </span><span class="head">Unified representation of entries</span></h3><p>In the current <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>, the TEI defines four different container elements that may serve as grouping devices for lexical information on the level of entries (the following definitions are taken from the TEI guidelines, emphasis added):</p><ol><li class="item"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>: contains a single <span style="font-style:italic">structured entry</span> in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><entryFree></span>: contains a single <span style="font-style:italic">unstructured entry</span> in any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon.</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><superEntry></span>: groups a sequence of entries within any kind of lexical resource, such as a dictionary or lexicon which function as a single unit, for example a set of homographs.</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><re></span>: (related entry) contains a dictionary entry for a lexical item related to the headword, such as a compound phrase or derived form, embedded inside a larger entry.</li></ol><p>These four elements can be used to distinguish types of entries along two conceptual axes:</p><ol><li class="item"><span style="font-weight:bold">Containing vs. contained entries</span>: entries may contain additional lexical information that can be conceived as an additional dictionary entry in its own right. Specifically, <span class="gi"><superEntry></span> may contain <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> in turn may contain <span class="gi"><re></span> to represent the embedding of lexical entries on three distinct levels. Due to <span class="gi"><re></span> being allowed to be used recursively, the number of levels for representing entry-like lexical information inside other such blocks is effectively unrestricted.</li><li class="item"><span style="font-weight:bold">Structured vs. unstructured entries</span>, i. e. entries that can readily be represented (in the lexical view) in the spirit of the TEI Guideline’s Dictionary Chapter (<a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>, <span class="gi"><re></span>) vs. entries that for some reason violate the generic content model of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> or <span class="gi"><re></span> and thus have to be represented more freely (<span class="gi"><entryFree></span>). A third category in this respect are entries that exhibit a highly reduced amount of lexical content while this content is still of essentially entry-like nature (<span class="gi"><superEntry></span>).</li></ol><p>In TEI Lex-0, we refrain from this overly complex cross-classification of entries with regard to their place within an entry hierarchy (first axis above) and the rigidity of the lexical structuring they exhibit (second axis above). Instead of using four different elements for entry-like objects, only <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> is used. In order to still be able to construct hierarchies of embedded entries, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> is in the context of TEI Lex-0 allowed to occur recursively (e.g. by making it part of model.entryPart.top). This is where TEI Lex-0 departs from the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>, but this <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/TEIC/TEI/issues/1791">issue</a> has already been raised with TEI.</p><p>In the context of TEI-Lex-0, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> is used to encode the basic element of the dictionary microstructure; it groups all the information related to a particular linguistic entity and may contain further entries related to it (e.g. homographs or compound phrases).</p><p>The substitution of <span class="gi"><re></span> and <span class="gi"><superEntry></span> by <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> is compatible with regard to the content model of the discarded elements. Both <span class="gi"><re></span> and <span class="gi"><superEntry></span> have content models that are proper subsets of the content model of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>. Instead of <span class="gi"><superEntry></span> which most typically is used as a mere container for grouping lexical entries, either an <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> grouping entries can be used or the mechanisms implemented by att.global.linking can be exploited.</p><p>Consider the following excerpt from the “Wörterbuch der deutschen Gegenwartssprache” (“Dictionary of Contemporary German”, WDG, 1964–1977). In the WDG, compounds with the same morphological dependant (but different heads) are grouped into nests. According to the current TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>, such a nest would most probably be serialized as follows:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e255" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><superEntry></span>
 <span class="element"><form></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>Haus-<span class="element"></orth></span>, <span class="element"><orth></span>haus-<span class="element"></orth></span>:<span class="element"></form></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- possibly some shared usg information --></span>
 <span class="element"><entry></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">expand</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Hausaltar</span>"></span>-altar<span class="element"></orth></span>, <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><gen <span class="attribute">value</span>="<span class="attributevalue">masculine</span>"></span>der<span class="element"></gen></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">expand</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Hausandacht</span>"></span>-andacht<span class="element"></orth></span>, <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><gen <span class="attribute">value</span>="<span class="attributevalue">feminine</span>"></span>die<span class="element"></gen></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- ... --></span>
<span class="element"></superEntry></span></div><p>In TEI-Lex-0, this nest of entries would be modelled as an <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> in its own right. Note that the former <span class="gi"><superEntry></span> was transformed into a typed entry (see <a class="link_ref" href="#TypesOfEntries" title="Types of entries">Types of entries</a> below for a detailed discussion of entry types):</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e298" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordFamily</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">base</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>Haus-<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><pc></span>,<span class="element"></pc></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">base</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>haus-<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><pc></span>:<span class="element"></pc></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- possibly some shared usg information --></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordForm</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">expand</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Hausaltar</span>"></span>-altar<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><pc></span>,<span class="element"></pc></span>
   <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><gen <span class="attribute">value</span>="<span class="attributevalue">masculine</span>"></span>der<span class="element"></gen></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordForm</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">expand</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Hausandacht</span>"></span>-andacht<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><pc></span>,<span class="element"></pc></span>
   <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><gen <span class="attribute">value</span>="<span class="attributevalue">feminine</span>"></span>die<span class="element"></gen></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- ... --></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>The same encoding strategy can be exploited when entries are grouped under a common morphological root as is customary for Arabic dictionaries such as the 48th edition of “The Dictionary of Language and Proper Nouns” (المنجد في اللغة والأعلام) presented below:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e336" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordFamily</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">root</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>ﺍﺮﻛ<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><pc></span>:<span class="element"></pc></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">١-</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordForm</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>ﺃَﺮَﻛَ<span class="element"></orth></span> -ُ ﺃُﺮُﻛًﺍ<span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span> ﺎﻠﺠﻤﻟُ: ﺎﻜﻟ ﻭﺮﻗ ﺍﻷﺭَﺎﻛِ ٠ ﺃَﺮَﻛَ ٠- ﺃَﺮَﻛًﺍ ﺎﻠﺠﻤﻟُ ﺎﺸﺘﻛﻯ ﺐﻄﻨﻫُ ﻢﻧ ﺄَﻜﻟ ﺍﻷﺭَﺎﻛِ ٠ ﺍﻷﺭﺎﻛ (ﻥ): ﻭﺎﺣﺪﺘﻫُ ﺃَﺭﺎﻛﺓ ﺝ ﺃُﺮُﻛ ﻭ ﺃَﺭَﺎﺌِﻛ. ﺶﺟﺭ ﺫﻭ ﺵﻮﻛ. ﻁﻮﻴﻟ ﺎﻠﺳﺎﻗ، ﻚﺜﻳﺭ
     ﺎﻟﻭﺮﻗ ﻭ ﺍﻸﻐﺻﺎﻧ. ﺥﻭَّﺍﺭ ﺎﻠﻋﻭﺩ ﺖﺘَّﺧﺫ ﻢﻨﻫ ﺎﻠﻤﺳﺍﻮﻴﻛ<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">٢٠ -</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordForm</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>ﺃَﺮَﻛَ<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span> ْ -َ ﺃَﺮَﻛًﺍ ﻭ ﺃَﺮِﻛَ ْ -ُ ﺃُﺮﻛًﺍ ﺎﻠﺟﺮﺣُ: ﺏﺭﺃَ<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- … --></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>Note that the embedded entries are enumerated by way of the attribute @n.</p><p>This type of grouping is also customarily used in dictionaries of word-families in other languages such as in Howard H. Keller’s (1978): “A German word family dictionary together with English equivalents”:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e361" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">wordFamily</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">main</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>Haus<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><pos></span>nn<span class="element"></pos></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">sub</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>
    <span class="element"><m></span>Häus<span class="element"></m></span>
    <span class="element"><m></span>chen<span class="element"></m></span>
   <span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">sub</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>
    <span class="element"><m></span>haus<span class="element"></m></span>
    <span class="element"><m></span>en<span class="element"></m></span>
   <span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>In the Collins/COBUILD “Dictionary of Idioms” (2nd. ed., 2002), idioms are grouped under a common headword. No additional information for the headword is provided; it only serves as part of the access structure for the idioms. This can also be modelled using recursive entries. Again, see <a class="link_ref" href="#TypesOfEntries" title="Types of entries">Types of entries</a> for a discussion of possible entry types:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e395" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">simple</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>house<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">multiWordExpression</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>bring the house down<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">multiWordExpression</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>eat someone out of house and home<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
 <span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">multiWordExpression</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>get on like a house on fire<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>...<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></entry></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>For <span class="gi"><entryFree></span>, the content model is defined more freely than for <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>. To account for entries that do not follow the rather strict lexical model envisioned by the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> for <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.dictScrap" title="<dictScrap>"><dictScrap></a> within <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> shall be used.</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.2_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">2.2. </span><span class="head">Changes to the content model of <span class="gi"><entry></span></span></h3><p>In TEI Lex-0, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> may contain the following elements: <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.form" title="<form>"><form></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.etym" title="<etym>"><etym></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pc" title="<pc>"><pc></a>, and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.dictScrap" title="<dictScrap>"><dictScrap></a>. Contrary to the current TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>, it may not directly contain the following elements: <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>, <span class="gi"><hom></span>, and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a>. See the section <a class="link_ref" href="#hp8vymhe6byi" title=""><span class="hi">Towards a more systematic use of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></span></a> below.</p><p>In TEI Lex-0, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> has a mandatory <span class="att">xml:id</span>.</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="TypesOfEntries"><h3><span class="headingNumber">2.3. </span><span class="head">Types of entries</span></h3><p>Based on the proposed definition for <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> in TEI-Lex-0, entries are conceived as “the most basic” elements of the microstructure. The examples provided in the section <span class="hi">Unified representation of entries</span> illustrate two applications of entries embedded within entries and make it obvious that different types of linguistic entities can be represented by <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> in one single dictionary. Therefore, the provision of a <span class="att">type</span> attribute for <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> is encouraged in such cases. The value for the type attribute shall denote a property of the entry as a whole that is not represented more specifically by way of other elements within the entry. It is for example <span style="font-style:italic">not</span> good practice to use the part-of-speech as the value for entry/@type because this information is encoded in gramGrp/pos.</p><p>The current TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> suggest the set of the following values for <span class="att">type</span>:</p><ul><li class="item">abbr</li><li class="item">affix</li><li class="item">foreign</li><li class="item">hom</li><li class="item">main</li><li class="item">sub</li><li class="item">supplemental</li><li class="item">xref</li></ul><p>Again, the list of values represent features from a considerable range of axes. Moreover, the features are not mutually exclusive (e.g. a foreign abbreviation may well be a homonym). The values belong to different domains: morphology (abbr), etymology (foreign), orthography and possibly phonology (hom), and (in a broad sense) the macrostructure of the dictionary (main, supplemental, xr). Of these domains, all except the dictionary’s macrostructure are catered for in specific elements below the level of the entry. They should therefore not be used as types of entries.</p><p>In general, the entry type can be applied locally for a single dictionary or globally to allow for classification across different dictionaries. Provided that a single dictionary will often comprise entries that describe linguistic entities of the same kind (“words”, word families, multi-word expressions, morphemes, …) a classification along those lines will be of minor importance for a stand-alone resource but may be useful in a multi-dictionary use-case. Possible values for this domain include:</p><ul><li class="item">affix</li><li class="item">word</li><li class="item">synset<span class="note" id="Note1"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">e.g. for onomasiological dictionaries</span></span><span class="note" id="Note2"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">… though this is not the primary concern of the TEI it reads elsewhere in this text. (Laurent?)</span></span></li><li class="item">multi-word-entity</li><li class="item">word-family</li></ul><p>A classification based on macrostructural properties (i. e. properties describing aspects of the internal organisation of a resource) can on the other hand be exploited both for a single dictionary and across different dictionaries. Possible values for this domain include:</p><ul><li class="item">main</li><li class="item">supplemental</li><li class="item">nest</li><li class="item">niche</li><li class="item">xr</li></ul><p><span class="hi">TODO: Priviledge one strategy (discussion)?</span> See this <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/12">issue</a> on GitHub.</p></div></div>
<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3"><h2><span class="headingNumber">3. </span><span class="head"><a id="hp8vymhe6byi"></a>Towards a more systematic use of <span class="gi"><sense></span></span></h2><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">3.1. </span><span class="head">Guidelines</span></h3><p>In the current TEI Dictionary Chapter, the content model of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a> allows one to have sense-related information directly within <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>. TEI Lex-0 proscribes a stricter use of these elements so that sense-related information is grouped within the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> element, in accordance with the underlying semasiological model implemented in the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>.</p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> should be therefore considered mandatory for any dictionary entry that actually provides sense information for the headword. Further in this document, we consider some additional specific cases e.g. “referencing” entries (entires that simply point to other entries) and inflexional lexica (dictionaries that describe word forms only), where <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> is not a mandatory child of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>.</p><p>As a consequence of making the use of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> more systematic within <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>, we have seen (see section on <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>) that some elements are no longer allowed as children of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>. We provide here a specific background for each of them:</p><ul><li class="item"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a> is clearly intended to provide a prose description of a meaning within a <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> element and should not appear in any other context;</li><li class="item">In the same way, it is recommended that <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> be used exclusively as a child of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a>, or when necessary within <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.dictScrap" title="<dictScrap>"><dictScrap></a>;</li><li class="item">The case of <span class="gi"><hom></span> is peculiar since it provides a subordinate organization to an entry which is redundant in relation to what <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> allows one to represent. <span class="gi"><hom></span> is not allowed in TEI Lex-0.</li></ul><p>Note: In the case one has to deal with information that does not fit a <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a>-based organization, for instance in the process of retro-digitizing an existing dictionary source, the use of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.dictScrap" title="<dictScrap>"><dictScrap></a> is recommended. Further step in the encoding of the lexical content may lead to a more precise encoding in a second phase.</p><p>In TEI Lex-0, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> has a mandatory <span class="att">xml:id</span>.</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">3.2. </span><span class="head">A limited number of possible contexts for <span class="gi"><def></span></span></h3><p>In the current TEI guidelines, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a> is allowed to be used within the following elements:</p><ul><li class="item">Module core: <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a></li><li class="item">Module dictionaries: <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.dictScrap" title="<dictScrap>"><dictScrap></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a>, <span class="gi"><entryFree></span>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.etym" title="<etym>"><etym></a>, <span class="gi"><hom></span>, <span class="gi"><re></span>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></li><li class="item">Module namesdates: <span class="gi"><nym></span></li></ul><p>TEI Lex-0 allows the use of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a> in <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a> and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.etym" title="<etym>"><etym></a> only. All other existing contexts would be implemented by embedding <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a> within a <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a>.</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3_div.3"><h3><span class="headingNumber">3.3. </span><span class="head"><a id="gg6wukfjt7e9"></a>Encoding sense in entries with multiple parts of speech</span></h3><p>For multi-POS lexical entries, TEI Lex-0 considers each POS as a trigger for a new sense. Consequently, we recommend encoding grammatical information in each sense coming after the first one to be serialised inside the semantic bloc as follows:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e757" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><sense></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><pos></span>..<span class="element"></pos></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"><def></span>..<span class="element"></def></span> .. 
<span class="element"></sense></span></div><p>Consider this example, where <span class="mentioned">arrest</span> appears both as a verb and a noun:</p><div class="figure"><img src="media/image25.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:6.720416666666667cm; height:4.709583333333334cm;"></img></div><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e772" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>

<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3_div.4"><h3><span class="headingNumber">3.4. </span><span class="head">Case of bilingual dictionaries</span></h3><div class="figure"><img src="media/image13.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:15.927916666666667cm; height:5.538611111111111cm;"></img><span class="caption">Excerpt from the entry <span class="mentioned">aid</span> from XXX</span></div><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e834" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>

<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.3_div.5"><h3><span class="headingNumber">3.5. </span><span class="head"><a id="tw5hp3zaa2wg"></a>Deprecating <span class="gi"><hom></span></span></h3><p>Making a clear difference between a situation where an entry has to be split into two or more homonyms and one where these differences correspond to a semantic alternation is lexicographically difficult. Still, the main danger in keeping both possibilities in the representation of a lexical entry in a digital lexicon is to introduce a systematic structural ambiguity as to where the appropriate information is to be found. We thus deprecate <span class="gi"><hom></span> altogether in the present recommendation and have this element be replaced by the appropriate <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> construct. For instance, the following example from the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1010" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>bray<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><pron></span>breI<span class="element"></pron></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><hom></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>n<span class="element"></gram></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>
   <span class="element"><def></span>cry of an ass; sound of a trumpet.<span class="element"></def></span>
  <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></hom></span>
 <span class="element"><hom></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>vt<span class="element"></gram></span>
   <span class="element"><subc></span>VP2A<span class="element"></subc></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>
   <span class="element"><def></span>make a cry or sound of this kind.<span class="element"></def></span>
  <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></hom></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>would in TEI Lex-0 be represented as:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1035" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>bray<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><pron></span>brel<span class="element"></pron></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><pos></span>n<span class="element"></pos></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>
   <span class="element"><def></span>cry of an ass<span class="element"></def></span>
  <span class="element"></sense></span>
  <span class="element"><pc></span>;<span class="element"></pc></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>
   <span class="element"><def></span>sound of a trumpet<span class="element"></def></span>
  <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"><pc></span>.<span class="element"></pc></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><pos></span>vt<span class="element"></pos></span>
   <span class="element"><subc></span>VP2A<span class="element"></subc></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><def></span>make a cry or sound of this kind<span class="element"></def></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"><pc></span>.<span class="element"></pc></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div></div>
<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4"><h2><span class="headingNumber">4. </span><span class="head"><a id="c325ri54eh64"></a>Written and Spoken Forms</span></h2><p>The current TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> allows for an extremely wide range of encoding possibilities for written and spoken forms. In the discussion which follows, we suggest ways in which the elements, in particular <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.form" title="<form>"><form></a>, can be constrained. We give examples of use types not covered by the <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>, and propose some extensions.</p><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.1. </span><span class="head"><a id="h2au7t2l5yeq"></a>A note on inheritance</span></h3><p>We assume that in order to determine the complete properties of an element inside the entry tree, the principle of default inheritance applies, e.g. grammatical properties of a form are determined by collecting the sibling <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a> of the ancestor-or-self of the focus element, where the superordinate grammatical properties can be overwritten by the lower-level properties. This principle is relatively straightforward in the case of grammatical properties, but more complex for the word paradigm, esp. in cases of variant forms. For more information c.f. Ide et al. (<a class="link_ref" href="https://www.kilgarriff.co.uk/Publications/2000-IdeKilgRomary-Euralex.pdf"><span class="hi">2000</span></a>) and Erjavec et al. (<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.lrec-conf.org/proceedings/lrec2000/html/summary/335.htm"><span class="hi">2000</span></a>).</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.2. </span><span class="head">Grammatical properties of lexical entries</span></h3><p>Grammatical properties of lexical entries should be specified in <code>entry/gramGrp</code>. This element will typically specify the part-of-speech of the entry.</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1106" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>on<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>prep<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span> ... 
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>Notes:</p><ol><li class="item">Grammatical properties of the entry should <span class="hi">not</span> be specified in <code>entry/form[@type="lemma"]/gramGrp</code></li><li class="item">In cases where headwords are discriminated only on the basis of their orthography (e.g. in English dictionaries which treat conversion pairs of nouns and verbs, such as <span class="hi">run</span>, as belonging in single entries), <code>entry/gramGrp</code> should not be used, because its role is taken over by the individual <code>sense/gramGrp</code>.</li></ol><div class="figure"><img src="media/image17.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:7.750422222222222cm; height:5.357813888888889cm;"></img></div><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1138" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>aid<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><pron></span>/ed/<span class="element"></pron></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><pos></span>noun<span class="element"></pos></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>1. help, especially money, <span class="element"><lb/></span>food or other gifts given to people living <span class="element"><lb/></span> in difficult conditions aid to the earth-<span class="element"><lb/></span>quake zone an aid worker (NOTE:
     This <span class="element"><lb/></span>meaning of aid has no plural.) in aid <span class="element"><lb/></span>of in order to help We give money in <span class="element"><lb/></span> aid of the Red Cross. They are collect-<span class="element"><lb/></span>ing money in aid of
     refugees<span class="element"></sense></span>
  <span class="element"><pc></span>. <span class="element"></pc></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>2. some-<span class="element"><lb/></span>thing which helps you to do something <span class="element"><lb/></span>kitchen aids<span class="element"></sense></span> í <span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><pos></span>verb<span class="element"></pos></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>1. to help some-<span class="element"><lb/></span>thing to happen<span class="element"></sense></span>
  <span class="element"><sense></span>2. to help someone<span class="element"></sense></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.3"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.3. </span><span class="head">Representation of the lemma</span></h3><p>The form element should always be qualified by its <span class="att">type</span>. The lemma (i.e. headword) form should be encoded as <code>form[@type="lemma"]</code>.</p><p>If it is necessary to specify the grammatical properties of the lemma form itself (as opposed to the grammatical properties of the entry), this is described by <code>entry/form[@type="lemma"]/gramGrp</code>, e.g.:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1201" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><orth></span>go<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">tense</span>"></span>present<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
<span class="element"></form></span></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.4"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.4. </span><span class="head"><a id="sgbbk809lx3"></a>Representation of inflected forms</span></h3><p>Dictionaries often include additional forms next to the lemma. In English, these are used to specify irregular forms, such as “corpus / corpora” or “take / took”, whereas in inflectionally rich languages they are often used to help the user determine the correct paradigm of the word (such as “krava / -e” in Slovene). </p><p>Such inflected forms should be encoded in <code>entry/form/@type="inflected"</code>, e.g.:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1219" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>go<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">inflected</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>went<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><tns></span>past<span class="element"></tns></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>... </p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.5"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.5. </span><span class="head"><a id="d34m89i7fkd"></a>Paradigms</span></h3><p>When several inflected forms can be present next to the lemma, these can be embedded into <code>entry/form[@type="paradigm"]</code>. The decision on whether to use this extra element depends on the particular dictionary and language.</p><p>The other use case for paradigms is when the full inflectional paradigm of the word is embedded in the entry, i.e. when the dictionary also includes all the word-forms of the words covered, which can be useful for example in machine processing. </p><p>An entry may contain several paradigms, e.g. a partial one for humans and a full one for machines, or one for each stem of a verb. Each paradigm type should be distinguished by the <span class="att">subtype</span> attribute.</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1248" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">perder</span>" <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">es</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>perder<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>verb<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">paradigm</span>" <span class="attribute">subtype</span>="<span class="attributevalue">present</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">inflected</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>pierdo<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><per></span>1<span class="element"></per></span>
    <span class="element"><number></span>sg<span class="element"></number></span>
    <span class="element"><mood></span>indic<span class="element"></mood></span>
    <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">voice</span>"></span>active<span class="element"></gram></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- other inflected forms (of present indicative) here --></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><tns></span>present<span class="element"></tns></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">paradigm</span>" <span class="attribute">subtype</span>="<span class="attributevalue">preteritum</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">inflected</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>perdí<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
    <span class="element"><per></span>1<span class="element"></per></span>
    <span class="element"><number></span>sg<span class="element"></number></span>
    <span class="element"><mood></span>indic<span class="element"></mood></span>
    <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">voice</span>"></span>active<span class="element"></gram></span>
   <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><tns></span>preteritum<span class="element"></tns></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span> ... 
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.6"><h3><span class="headingNumber">4.6. </span><span class="head">Representation of variants</span></h3><p>The representation of variation within a form is highly dependant upon the specifics of the features of the variation and the way in which they vary. However, as a general principle, variation may be encoded as <code>form[@type="variant"]</code> and embedded within the parent element for which a subordinate feature exhibits variation.</p><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.6_div.1"><h4><span class="headingNumber">4.6.1. </span><span class="head">Orthographic variation</span></h4><p>Several kinds of orthographic variation may be distinguished. Below, we present some of the options with the corresponding examples.</p><p>Spelling variation due to change in language’s orthography convention:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1305" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Flussschifffahrt</span>"
 <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">de</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">compound</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">segmeted</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Fluss<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>schifffahrt<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>
    <span class="element"><seg></span>Fluss<span class="element"></seg></span>
    <span class="element"><pc></span>-<span class="element"></pc></span>
    <span class="element"><seg></span>Schifffahrt<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">notAfter</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1996</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><seg></span>Fluß<span class="element"></seg></span>
    <span class="element"><seg></span>schifffahrt<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><usg <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">time</span>"></span>Vor 1996 Rechtschreibung Reform<span class="element"></usg></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
   <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>noun<span class="element"></gram></span>
  <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span> .... 
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>The following example is from American English in which due to the lack of official conventions for transliteration of Arabic orthography to the English (Latin) script, the initial vowel in the surname ‘Osama Bin Laden’ varies between ‘O’ and ‘U’:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1335" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><pron <span class="attribute">notation</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ipa</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><seg <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ousma</span>" <span class="attribute">corresp</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#usma #osma</span>"></span>ow."sa.ma<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"><seg></span>bɪn<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"><seg></span>ˈlaːdn̹<span class="element"></seg></span>
 <span class="element"></pron></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">transliterated</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><seg <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">osma</span>"
    <span class="attribute">corresp</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#usma #ousma</span>"></span>Osama<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Bin<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Laden<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">transliterated</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><seg <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">usma</span>"
    <span class="attribute">corresp</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#osma #ousma</span>"></span>Usama<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Bin<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Laden<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
<span class="element"></form></span></div></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.6_div.2"><h4><span class="headingNumber">4.6.2. </span><span class="head">Phonetic Variation</span></h4><p>In this example, the entry contains the single orthographic form as a direct child of the lemma and phonetic transcriptions of the two roughly equally used variant pronunciations of the word 'caramel' from American English.</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1365" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">caramel-en</span>" <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en-US</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>caramel<span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><pron <span class="attribute">notation</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ipa</span>"></span>'keɹə"mɛl<span class="element"></pron></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><pron <span class="attribute">notation</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ipa</span>"></span>'kaɹmɫ̩<span class="element"></pron></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>noun<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- ... --></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div><p>We have an open GitHub <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/16">issue</a> related to this.</p></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.4_div.6_div.3"><h4><span class="headingNumber">4.6.3. </span><span class="head">Regional or dialectal Variation</span></h4><p>In the following example from Mixtepec-Mixtec, there is variation in the form of the word for the city of Oaxaca between speakers from the village of Yucanany and the rest of the speakers. Since the Yucanany variety makes up only a small portion of the speakers of the language, this case of variation is represented as an embedded <code>form[@type="variant"]</code> within the lemma. Note the use of <code>usg[@type="geo"]/placeName</code> to explicitly specify this feature in addition to the use of the private language subtag (<code>xml:lang="mix-x-YCNY"</code>) as per <span class="ref">BCP 47</span>.</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1402" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">Oaxaca-MIX</span>" <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">mix</span>"
 <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">compound</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Ñuu<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>Ntua<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"></orth></span>
  <span class="element"><pron <span class="attribute">notation</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ipa</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>ɲùù<span class="element"></seg></span>
   <span class="element"><seg></span>nd̪ùá<span class="element"></seg></span>
  <span class="element"></pron></span>
  <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">variant</span>"
   <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">mix-x-YCNY</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><orth></span>Ntua<span class="element"></orth></span>
   <span class="element"><pron <span class="attribute">notation</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ipa</span>"></span>nd̪ùá<span class="element"></pron></span>
   <span class="element"><usg <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">geo</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><placeName></span>Yucanany<span class="element"></placeName></span>
   <span class="element"></usg></span>
  <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><gramGrp></span>
  <span class="element"><gram <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">pos</span>"></span>locationNoun<span class="element"></gram></span>
 <span class="element"></gramGrp></span> ... 
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div></div></div>
<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5"><h2><span class="headingNumber">5. </span><span class="head">Structured lexical references (<code>xr/ref</code>)</span></h2><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">5.1. </span><span class="head">Motivation</span></h3><p>The current TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> provide several mechanisms by means of which one item of lexical information can refer to another, e.g.:</p><ul><li class="item"><span class="gi"><gloss></span> for the provision of simple (non refined) translation equivalents of the head word</li><li class="item"><span class="tag"><usg type="synonym">></span> for synonym references</li><li class="item"><code>cit[@type="translation"]/quote</code> for translation equivalents in bilingual or translation dictionaries</li><li class="item"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.oRef" title="<oRef>"><oRef></a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pRef" title="<pRef>"><pRef></a> for the resolution of “~" headword placeholders in quotations and other dictionary text</li><li class="item"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a>, <span class="gi"><ref></span> as a general cross-referencing mechanism</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><ptr></span> as a pointer to another location</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><link></span></li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><mentioned></span> in the etymology section</li><li class="item"><span class="gi"><term></span> for mentions of technical terms</li></ul><p>In keeping with the approach of the TEI Lex-0, and considering that links/relations between lexical data elements are increasingly part of the core lexical data model rather than mere convenience pointers for dictionary users, we need a more unified and more constrained mechanism for lexical references, whether they point to an existing lexical entity in some dictionary or lexicon, or in a more general way to lexical objects without a target reference. </p><p>The proposed mechanism has the following properties </p><ol><li class="item">It applies only to references with a clear <span style="font-style:italic">linguistic</span> meaning.</li><li class="item">The number of arbitrary (or context-dependent) choices for the encoder is minimal; the semantics of the reference should not depend on context</li><li class="item">The relation between the encoding dictionary content and the underlying/implied lexical data model should be as transparent as possible</li><li class="item">No drastic changes to the TEI guidelines are needed, except for minor changes within the dictionary module</li></ol><p>In the following we first present the recommended encoding, and then elicit how existing alternatives can be replaced accordingly.</p></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">5.2. </span><span class="head">Proposal: Using <span class="gi"><ref></span> and <span class="gi"><xr></span> to point to lexical entities</span></h3><p>In TEI Lex-0, we use <span class="gi"><ref></span> as the general element for a lexical reference and <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a> as the enclosing element that groups information related to this reference. The reference may be internal to a dictionary or pointing to an external source, even when the actual target lexical object is not explicitly known. In the latter case, <span class="gi"><ref></span> can be used without an explicit pointing attribute. Furthermore the actual intended target of the reference can be of various possible types, namely a full entry, but also a specific sense, form or morpheme within a given entry.</p><p>For all such uses, the following attributes may be used on <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a> and <span class="gi"><ref></span>:</p><ul><li class="item"><span class="att">type</span> is a mandatory attribute on <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a> for a lexical reference. Its default value is "lexical" and can be superseded (or complemented by means of <span class="att">subtype</span>). It should be an indication of the lexical relation between the headword of the entry and the object referred to (cf. next subsection)</li><li class="item"><code>ref/@type</code> may be an indication of the target object category (entry, sense, ….) See this <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/20">issue</a> on GitHub.</li><li class="item"><span class="att">xml:lang</span>, which is recommended when <span class="gi"><ref></span> actually contains an explicit lexical form</li><li class="item"><code>ref/@target</code>: to point to the actual lexical object being pointed at when applicable</li><li class="item"><code>ref/@notation</code> to indicate, like we currently do on <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a> or <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pron" title="<pron>"><pron></a> the actual notation used for the explicit lexical form when provided</li></ul><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.2_div.1"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.2.1. </span><span class="head">Typology for <code>xr/@type</code> values</span></h4><p>We suggest an extensible list of values, including “cf" for general references which do not have clear semantics.</p><div class="table"><table class="rules" style="border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;"><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">value of @type</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">description</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">example</td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">lexical</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">default (root of hierarchy)</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">cognate</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">link to cognate in other language. See this <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/19">issue</a> on GitHub.</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1606" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>voice<span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><etym></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">cognate</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">sa</span>"></span>वाच्<span class="element"></ref></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
 <span class="element"></etym></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">etymon</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">link to (possibly reconstructed) root form</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1620" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>voice<span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><etym></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">etymon</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">target</span>="<span class="attributevalue">http://indo-european.info/pokorny-etymological-dictionary/u%CC%AFek%CA%B7.htm</span>"
    <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">PIE</span>"></span>u̯ekʷ-<span class="element"></ref></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
 <span class="element"></etym></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">synonym, hyponym, hyperonym, antonym , meronym (etc.) </td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1633" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>dog<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">hyperonym</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"
    <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">entry</span>"></span>mammal<span class="element"></ref></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">translationEquivalent</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">translation equivalent</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1648" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>horrify<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translationEquivalent</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>"></span>horrifier<span class="element"></ref></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">cf</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">Untyped cross-reference</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e1663" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
