  <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">nl</span>"
   <span class="attribute">target</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#M012340</span>"></span>burcht<span class="element"></ref></span>
 <span class="element"></xr></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr></table></div></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.2_div.2"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.2.2. </span><span class="head">Suggested values of ref/@target</span></h4><p>Cf: <a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SAXP"><span class="hi">http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SAXP</span></a></p><ul><li class="item"># + xml:id: reference to element by xml:id inside current document</li><li class="item">URI reference</li><li class="item">xpath/xpointer expressions, using TEI xpointer schemes (<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SATS"><span class="hi">http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/SA.html#SATS</span></a>) See <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/23">GitHub issue</a>.</li><li class="item">#null: there is no concrete reference</li></ul></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.2_div.3"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.2.3. </span><span class="head"><a id="tzhvjc2d1p07"></a>How TEI Lex-0 differs from TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span></span></h4><p>This section is still not properly encoded.</p><div class="table"><table class="rules" style="border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;"><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">description</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">current encoding</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">proposed encoding</td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">synonyms, hyponyms, hyperonyms (and other semantic relations)</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><usg type="synonym">Hund</usg></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><xr type="synonym"><br></br><span>   </span><ref target="http://woerterbuchnetz.de/DWB/?sigle=DWB&amp;mode=Vernetzung&amp;lemid=GH13199#XGH13199" xml:lang="de">Hund</ref><br></br><span class="hi"></xr></span></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">abbreviated headword occurrence in quotations</td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><p>academy … The Royal A~ of Arts OALD</p> <p><span class="gi"><q></span><br></br> The Royal<br></br> <oRef type="cap" /><br></br> of Arts<br></br></q></p></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><span class="gi"><q></span><br></br> The Royal<br></br> <xr type="headwordAttestation"><br></br><span>      </span><ref target="#current_entry_id">A~</ref><br></br><span>   </span></xr><br></br> of Arts<br></br></q></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">translation of headword (possibly in a particular senses/context)<span id="ftn2_return"><a class="notelink" title="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/examples-cit.html" href="#ftn2"><sup>2</sup></a></span></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.form" title="<form>"><form></a></span><br></br><span>      </span><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>to horrify</orth><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></form></span><br></br><span>   </span><cit type="translation" xml:lang="en"><br></br><span>      </span><span class="gi"><quote></span>horrifier</quote><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></cit></span><br></br><span>   </span><cit type="example"><br></br><span>      </span><span class="gi"><quote></span>she was horrified at the expense.</quote><br></br><span>      </span><cit type="translation" xml:lang="en"><br></br><span>         </span><span class="gi"><quote></span>elle était horrifiée par la dépense.</quote><br></br><span>      </span><span class="hi"></cit></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></cit></span><br></br><span class="hi"></entry></span></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a></span><br></br><span>   </span><form type="lemma"><br></br><span>      </span><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>horrify</orth><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></form></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></span><br></br><span>      </span><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a></span><br></br><span>         </span><ref type="translationEquivalent" xml:lang="fr">horrifier</ref><br></br><span>      </span><span class="hi"></xr></span><br></br><span>      </span><cit type="example"><br></br><span>         </span><span class="gi"><quote></span>she was horrified at the expense.</quote><br></br><span>         </span><cit type="translation"<span id="ftn3_return"><a class="notelink" title="Note that we do not change the encoding of the example" href="#ftn3"><sup>3</sup></a></span> xml:lang="en"><br></br><span>            </span><span class="gi"><quote></span>elle était horrifiée par la dépense.</quote><br></br><span>         </span><span class="hi"></cit></span><br></br><span>      </span><span class="hi"></cit></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></sense></span><br></br><span class="hi"></entry></span></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;">collocates in gramGrp<span id="ftn4_return"><a class="notelink" title="This is not replaced, but may be complemented by the reference mechanism" href="#ftn4"><sup>4</sup></a></span></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a></span><br></br><span>   </span><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.colloc" title="<colloc>"><colloc></a>stray</colloc><br></br><span class="hi"></gramGrp></span></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><span class="hi"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"><colloc</span><span class="note" id="Note6"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">we might also right away think of a place to hold grammatical information, on the function of the collocate (is it a subject or an object, etc.) and its category/features</span></span><span class="hi">></span><br></br><span>      </span><xr type="collocation"><br></br><span>         </span><ref target="http://www.oed.com/view/Entry/191378?rskey=WgfOMW&amp;result=2&amp;isAdvanced=false#eid">stray</ref><br></br><span>      </span><span class="hi"></xr></span><br></br><span>   </span><span class="hi"></colloc></span><br></br><span class="hi"></gramGrp></span></td></tr></table></div></div></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.3"><h3><span class="headingNumber">5.3. </span><span class="head"><span class="gi"><xr></span> and <span class="gi"><ref></span>: further examples</span></h3><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.3_div.1"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.3.1. </span><span class="head">Simple cross-reference to an entry</span></h4><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e2002" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>borcht<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">crossReference</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><lbl></span>Cf.<span class="element"></lbl></span>
  <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">target</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#M012340</span>"></span>burcht<span class="element"></ref></span>
 <span class="element"></xr></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.3_div.2"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.3.2. </span><span class="head">More complex example including quotations</span></h4><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e2015" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry></span>
 <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><orth></span>dog<span class="element"></orth></span>
 <span class="element"></form></span>
 <span class="element"><sense></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translationEquivalent</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><lbl></span>Male or unknown gender<span class="element"></lbl></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">entry</span>"></span>chien<span class="element"></ref></span>
   <span class="element"><cit></span>
    <span class="element"><quote <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>"></span> Le matin j'ouvre au <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">headwordAttestation</span>"></span>
      <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">entry</span>"></span>chien<span class="element"></ref></span>
     <span class="element"></xr></span> et je lui fais manger sa soupe. Le soir je lui siffle de venir se coucher<span class="element"></quote></span>
    <span class="element"><bibl></span>RENARD, Poil de Carotte, 1894, p. 102.<span class="element"></bibl></span>
    <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translation</span>"></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- included in the french cit, otherwise relation is lost --></span>
     <span class="element"><quote <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>In the morning, I open the door for the dog, and i ...<span class="element"></quote></span>
    <span class="element"></cit></span>
    <span class="element"><bibl></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- If the translation is from a published source, there could be a bibl here as well --></span>
    <span class="element"></bibl></span>
   <span class="element"></cit></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
  <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translationEquivalent</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><lbl></span>Female<span class="element"></lbl></span>
   <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">entry</span>"></span>chienne<span class="element"></ref></span>
   <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">fr</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><quote></span>6. Les fleuristes, murmura Lorilleux, toutes des Marie-couche-toi-là. Eh bien! Et moi? reprit la grande veuve, les lèvres pincées. Vous êtes galant.
         Vous savez, je ne suis pas une <span class="element"><xr <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">the_type_formerly_known_as_oref</span>"></span>
      <span class="element"><ref <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">entry</span>"></span>chienne<span class="element"></ref></span>
     <span class="element"></xr></span> , je ne me mets pas les pattes en l'air, quand on siffle! <span class="element"></quote></span>
    <span class="element"><bibl></span>ZOLA, L'Assommoir, 1877, p. 681.<span class="element"></bibl></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- possible translation --></span>
    <span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">translation</span>"></span>…..<span class="element"></cit></span>
   <span class="element"></cit></span>
  <span class="element"></xr></span>
 <span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"></entry></span></div></div><div class="teidiv2" id="index.xml-body.1_div.5_div.3_div.3"><h4><span class="headingNumber">5.3.3. </span><span class="head">Synonym, hyperonym, etc as (part of) a definition (“synonym definition", “genus proximum”)</span></h4><p>Under consideration. See this <a class="link_ref" href="https://github.com/DARIAH-ERIC/lexicalresources/issues/24">issue</a> on GitHub.</p></div></div></div>
<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.6"><h2><span class="headingNumber">6. </span><span class="head"><a id="gr771794udc1"></a>Usage information</span></h2><p>In the current TEI guidelines, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> is defined as an element which marks up “usage information in a dictionary entry”. Prototypically, usage information is a label which can be attached at various points in the entry hierarchy in order to signal e. g. restrictions in terms of geographic regions, domains of specialized language or stylistic properties for the particular lexical item that it is attached to.</p><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.6_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">6.1. </span><span class="head"><a id="m9dbyf3zkcmv"></a>Label-like vs. narrative usage descriptions</span></h3><p>Usage information ca be provided in dictionaries both in the form of label-like descriptors (often abbreviated) and as fuller narrative expressions.</p><p>Consider, for instance, the following senses taken from a German entry for Pflaume “plum” where usage information is provided by labels taken from fixed sets of values for stylistic and diatopic properties:</p><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e2084" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><sense <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><def <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">de</span>"></span>Frucht des Pflaumenbaums<span class="element"></def></span>
 <span class="element"><def <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>fruit of the plum tree<span class="element"></def></span>
<span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"><sense <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">2</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><usg <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">register</span>" <span class="attribute">norm</span>="<span class="attributevalue">colloquial</span>"></span>ugs.<span class="element"></usg></span>
 <span class="element"><def <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">de</span>"></span>Pflaumenbaum<span class="element"></def></span>
 <span class="element"><def <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">en</span>"></span>plum tree<span class="element"></def></span>
<span class="element"></sense></span>
<span class="element"><sense <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">3</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><usg <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">style</span>" <span class="attribute">norm</span>="<span class="attributevalue">casual</span>"></span>salopp<span class="element"></usg></span>
 <span class="element"><usg <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">style</span>" <span class="attribute">norm</span>="<span class="attributevalue">expletive</span>"></span>Schimpfwort<span class="element"></usg></span>

The sample is taken from a Serbian dialect dictionary. The quote in the dialect is further qualified by a usage hint: “(said by a peasant woman in the field in hot weather)” which provides a particular context in which the quote was recorded.</p><div class="table"><table class="rules" style="border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;"><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e2120" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><cit <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">example</span>"></span>

(corpus based dictionary with frequency information)oldest attestation: date + location of oldest attestation of an entry in a corpus based dictionary: usage?</span></span></span></h3><p>USAGE FURTHER INVESTIGATED: <a class="link_ref" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/10xxYwTSrAk1otrkOCZCIwE79VhTjObqmTRhpKosipyU/edit#heading=h.selhcccybq1y">https://docs.google.com/document/d/10xxYwTSrAk1otrkOCZCIwE79VhTjObqmTRhpKosipyU/edit#heading=h.selhcccybq1y</a></p><p>In lexicographic literature, usage information is not always uniformly classified. Compare, for instance, Svendsen (2009): </p><div class="figure"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/uXnKDcE.png" alt="(image taken from Marcin Overgaard, Theoretical Considerations for the Improvement of Usage Labelling in Dictionaries: a Combined Formal-Functional Approach. In: International Journal of Lexicography, Vol. 23 No. 4, pp. 411–442.)" class="graphic"></img></div><p>and Atkins and Rundell (2008) </p><div class="figure"><img src="https://i.imgur.com/RDyjhtm.png" alt="B.T. Atkins and M. Rundell, The Oxford Guide to Practical Lexicography. Oxford University Press, 2008, p. 183" class="graphic"></img></div><p>Svendsen and Atkins and Rundell can, however, be mapped against each other – with the exception of one category which is present only in the latter: </p><div class="table"><table><tr><td>Svendsen</td><td>Atkins and Rundell</td><td>Examples</td><td>Summary</td></tr><tr><td>Diachronic marking (Time)</td><td>Time</td><td>arch., dated, ...</td><td>TIME</td></tr><tr><td>Diatopic marking (Place)</td><td>Region</td><td>AmE., dial. ...</td><td>GEO</td></tr><tr><td>Diaintegrative marking (Nationality)</td><td>-</td><td>Lat., ...</td><td>LANGUAGE</td></tr><tr><td>Diastratic marking (Socio-Cultural)</td><td>Register / Style</td><td>formal, informal, journalese ...</td><td>SOCIO-CULTURAL</td></tr><tr><td>Diatechnical marking (Technicality)</td><td>Domain</td><td>Mil., Biol., ...</td><td>DOMAIN</td></tr><tr><td>Diafrequential marking (Frequency)</td><td></td><td></td><td>FREQUENCY</td></tr><tr><td>Diaevaluative marking (Attitude)</td><td>Attitude</td><td>pejor., iron., ...</td><td>ATTITUDE</td></tr><tr><td>Dianormative marking (Normativity)</td><td></td><td></td><td>NORMATIVITY</td></tr><tr><td></td><td>Meaning type</td><td>Lit., Fig. ...</td><td>MEANING TYPE</td></tr></table></div><p>In TEI, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> is a typed element. The type of a <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> element can be conceived as a conceptual axis (independent from other types) along which the given value of the element is located. The TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> offer a range of sample values for types to illustrate potential uses of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a>, but not al of them have been carried over to TEI Lex-0. The following table shows the differences between suggested values of <span class="att">type</span> in TEI and the required values of <span class="att">type</span> in TEI Lex-0:</p><div class="table"><table class="rules" style="border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;"><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"></td></tr></table></div><p>In TEI-Lex-0:</p><ol><li class="item">The <span class="att">type</span> attribute is made mandatory.</li><li class="item">The element <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> is used in a narrower sense than is currently the case in the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span>.</li><li class="item">The <span class="att">norm</span> attribute is encouraged.</li></ol><p>Justification:</p><ol><li class="item">Without <span class="att">type</span> attribute, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> would be an underspecified element. Usage labels describe a wide range of linguistic phenomena. Classifying them should be considered a good practice.</li><li class="item">Currently, the TEI <span style="font-style:italic">Guidelines</span> contain an overuse of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> for describing phenomena that could be covered by alternative, more narrowly defined TEI elements. It should be considered a good practice to use the most specific TEI element available. See table above and the next section <a class="link_ref" href="#RestristingUsg" title="Restricting the scope of usg">Restricting the scope of <span class="gi"><usg></span></a></li><li class="item">It is good practice to normalize the values of the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> elements because dictionaries are not always consistent in the way they use their usage labels. For instance, abbreviated and unabbreviated labels can appear in the same dictionary: they should be normalized to a single value. Normalization should be only restricted to a single dictionary. A global normalization effort is currently beyond the scope of TEI Lex-0.</li></ol></div><div class="teidiv1" id="RestristingUsg"><h3><span class="headingNumber">6.3. </span><span class="head"><a id="bw70jei7p4qf"></a>Restricting the scope of <span class="gi"><usg></span></span></h3><ol><li class="item"><p>Do not use <span class="tag"><usg type="lang"></span> to mark up the name of a language in an etymological or other discussion. The recommended way to encode this information is using <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.lang" title="<lang>"><lang></a> element within <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.etym" title="<etym>"><etym></a>.</p> <p>INCORRECT</p> <div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e2513" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entryFree <span class="attribute">xml:id</span>="<span class="attributevalue">MZ.RGJS.сајдисльк</span>"></span>

The recommended way to encode lexical relations is using the reference mechanism provided by <span class="tag"><xr type="syn"></span>. TOMA TODO: add examples</li><li class="item">Do not use <span class="tag"><usg type="colloc"></span> or for that matter "comp.", "obj.", "subj.", "verb" etc., but rather <span class="tag"><colloc type="object"></span> or <span class="tag"><colloc type="preposition"></span>.</li><li class="item"><span class="tag"><usg type="hint"></span> should be used as fallback for cases where the usage information does not fall into one of the recognized cases discussed above.</li><li class="item">Frequency information on lexicographic entities may differ from other types of usage information in that it often cannot be interpreted without further context. In phrases such as “mostly biology” or “rarely used in American English” it serves the purpose of a modifier (quantifier) to another usage information (or other lexical information). Such use calls for modeling the frequency information as an attribute to the usg element modified. For frequency information provided explicitly (e.g. corpus frequencies), a separate element should be introduced. TODO</li></ol><p><span class="hi">stuff to think about:</span></p><ul><li class="item"><span class="hi">Frequency and source corpus? ie. source attribute <usg type=”frequency” unit=???? source= “this_and_that_corpus”>12</usg>  </span></li></ul><p>Sample from Althochdeutsches Wörterbuch, feel free to annotate:</p><div class="figure"><img src="media/image27.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:10.874375cm; height:3.889375cm;"></img></div><p>Text:</p><p>aba-nemanto adv.; vgl. mhd. abenemende part.-adj.</p><p>(vgl. Findebuch S. 2). - Graff 11,1063 s. v. abaneman.</p><p>aba-nemend-: -o Np 45,10 (Ausg. K.-T getrennt</p><p>geschr.); -a Npw 9 (getrennt geschr.).</p><p>etw. beendend, mit abstr. Akk.: uuieo tuot er diu?</p><p>abanemendo dia uuiga . unz ze ende dero erdo aufe-</p><p>rens bella usque adfines terrae NpNpw 45,10 (= Npw 9).</p><p>Here is a typical WNT dictScrap (“kopje”) (<a class="link_ref" href="http://gtb.inl.nl/iWDB/search?actie=article&wdb=WNT&id=M073402"><span class="hi">http://gtb.inl.nl/iWDB/search?actie=article&wdb=WNT&id=M073402</span></a>)</p><p>— VERKEN —, znw. onz., mv. -s. Oorspr. is verken de alg. vorm in de mnl. schrijftaal, doch deze wordt naderhand, vooral in de 17de e., door holl. varken verdrongen. Verken, dat buiten Holland de gewone vorm in de dial. is, komt nog bij zndl. schrijvers voor. De uit het mnl. bekende meervoudsvorm varken, verken vindt men nog in de 16de en 17de e. (O. Rechtsbr. v. Steenb. 81 [1504]; Gem. Duytsche Spreckw. H 5 r° [1550]; gruterus 2, 129 [1611]; zie nog cats 2, 320 b [1656], echter in het rijm); de eveneens mnl. formatie varkene(n), verkene(n) komt nog tot in de 17de e. voor (v. dillen, Bedrijfslev. Amst. 1, 199 [1550]; Utr. Placaatb. 3, 674 a [1617]). De thans eenig gebruikelijke meervoudsvorm op -s is pas in de 15de e. voor het eerst aangetroffen (posthumus, Leidsche Textielnijverh. 1, 157 [1436], R. v. Zieriks. 281 [1485].) Het verkl. verksken (zie Teuthon. [1477]; junius, Nomencl. 57 a [1567]; kil. [1574]; heerman, Annot. 207 a [1642]) is in Z.-Nederl. de gewone vorm (j. joos, Schetsen en Schertsen 124 [1906]); varkske(n) (timmermans, Anna-Marie 47 [1921]) sluit aan bij een gedepalataliseerd brab. varken. Thans in de cultuurtaal alleen varkentje.</p><p>Mnl. verken, varken naast ouder verkin (reeds 1208 als bijnaam, zie H. Top. Dial. 20, 54), varkin; mnd. verken, varken, nnd. ferken, farken, varken; nhd. ferken (< nd.). Verken is de uit germ. *farχîna- ontstane umlautsvorm (zie v. wijk [1912]) met depalatalisatie tot varken en overgang χ > k in de inlaut (verg. hd. ferkel < ohd.farhilî(n)). Eig., evenals veulen en kuiken, het ter aanduiding van het jonge dier gebruikte gesubstantiveerde neutrum van een met -în-suffix gevormd bnw. (verg. lat.taurînus, suînus) — met een diminutieve bet., die in het mnl. soms nog merkbaar is — bij germ. *farχaz: oeng. fearh, neng. (veroud.) farrow (verg. to farrow); ohd. farh, farah, mhd. varch, nhd. (dial.) farch, fark ”big, varken”; verg. zwe. fargalt ”ever”; buiten het germ. lat. porcus; iersch orc (< *pork); lit. pa᪇szas ”gecastreerd varken”; ksl. prasę ”big”. Zie verder Ts. 67, Afl. 2.</p></div></div>

<div class="teidiv0" id="index.xml-body.1_div.8"><h2><span class="headingNumber">8. </span><span class="head">Misc. examples (these are various leftovers, TODO cleanup)</span></h2><p><span class="hi">Example discussed at ENel WG2 Budapest</span></p><ul><li class="item">Example from A DICTIONARY OF MANGAREVA (OR GAMBIER ISLANDS)</li></ul><p><span class="hi">The original text:</span></p><p><span class="hi">AGAI</span> ( àgài), adopted or adoptive. Ex. Motua agai, an adoptive</p><p>father, a foster­father. To nurse; to nurture. To give food to. 2.</p><p>To manure the ground. 3. To impregnate female flowers with</p><p>those of the male.</p><p>Aka­agai, to nourish; to feed. Plural akaagaigai.</p><p><span class="hi">The TEI-Lex0 encoding:</span></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a></p><p><form type="lemma"></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>AGAI</orth></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pc" title="<pc>"><pc></a>(</pc> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pron" title="<pron>"><pron></a>àgài</pron><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pc" title="<pc>"><pc></a>)</pc> <span class="hi"><!-- dictscrap vs pc --></span></p><p></form></p><p><sense n="1"></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>adopted or adoptive.</def> <span class="hi"><!-- should/could translation equivalent rather than <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a> --></span></p><p><cit type="example"></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.lbl" title="<lbl>"><lbl></a>Ex.</lbl></p><p><span class="gi"><quote></span> Motua agai,</quote></p><p><cit type="translation"></p><p><span class="gi"><quote></span>an adoptive father, a foster­father.</quote></p><p></cit></p><p></cit> </p><p></sense></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>To nurse; to nurture. To give food to.</def></p><p></sense></p><p></sense></p><p><sense n="2"> 2.</p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>To manure the ground.</def></p><p></sense> </p><p><sense n="3">3. </p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>To impregnate female flowers with</p><p>those of the male.</def></p><p></sense></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a></p><p><form type="compound"></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>Aka­agai,</orth></p><p></form></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a> to nourish; to feed.</sense></p><p><form type="inflected"></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a>Plural akaagaigai.</gramGrp></p><p></form></p><p></entry></p><p></entry></p><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.8_div.1"><h3><span class="headingNumber">8.1. </span><span class="head"><a id="y9mzqi58dztc"></a>X.2.</span></h3><p>from Milena Hebal-Jezierska’s Czech-Polish dictionary (discussed after the meeting in Budapest). </p><div class="figure"><img src="media/image16.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:17.832916666666666cm; height:5.675313888888889cm;"></img></div><p>Piotr’s suggestion follows (and it’s meant as food for thought / basis for discussion):</p><div class="figure"><img src="media/image9.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:14.44625cm; height:17.30375cm;"></img></div><p>Please note: (1) I am not taking a stance on how to encode equivalents. I simply used what I felt relatively comfortable with. (2) I had nothing to say about <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.usg" title="<usg>"><usg></a> -- I copied Milena’s suggestion.</p><p>I see several issues that are particularly worth discussion here:</p><ol><li class="item"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.colloc" title="<colloc>"><colloc></a> However we decide to encode it, let us use a solution that offers structural space for grammatical (and other) description of the collocate</li><li class="item">note the highlighted @resp at the level of <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a>. This is Milena’s “intrusion” into the scanned data. She is responsible for the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.cit" title="<cit>"><cit></a>, so it should be “@resp-able”. Probably nearly every element inside the entry should. OR: we (ab)use @decls mechanism for descriptions of such changes. OR (best?) we create a @tlex:change attribute that references a single <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.change" title="<change>"><change></a> in the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.revisionDesc" title="<revisionDesc>"><revisionDesc></a>.</li><li class="item">I used <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.oRef" title="<oRef>"><oRef></a> on purpose here, because I got startled when I saw the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a> alternative. I am not saying it’s wrong, but I think we also need a shorthand expression (I will add some prose on that)</li><li class="item">“kuty na cztery nogi” is an idiomatic expression headed by the passive adjectival participle kuty. It would be lemmatized under kuć , probably as a <span class="gi"><re></span> (or an equivalent). I mention this to make sure that, if we end up using <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a> for encoding translation equivalents, we also find a way to handle such cases.</li></ol></div><div class="teidiv1" id="index.xml-body.1_div.8_div.2"><h3><span class="headingNumber">8.2. </span><span class="head"><a id="avzo8orot7rp"></a>X.3.</span></h3><p>From Joanna Bilińska’s Budapest presentation</p><div class="figure"><img src="media/image14.jpg" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:15.92cm; height:3.7394444444444446cm;"></img></div><p>Entry that we’ve arrived at in Budapest:</p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.entry" title="<entry>"><entry></a></p><p><form type="lemma"> </p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>BODŁO</orth></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pc" title="<pc>"><pc></a>,</pc> <!--we don't like this, need better solution for commas--></p><p></form></p><p><form type="ending"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.orth" title="<orth>"><orth></a>a</orth></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.pc" title="<pc>"><pc></a>,</pc></p><p></form></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.gramGrp" title="<gramGrp>"><gramGrp></a></p><p><gen value="neutrum">n.</gen></p><p></gramGrp></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.sense" title="<sense>"><sense></a></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.def" title="<def>"><def></a>bobo, straszydło, potwora, dziwotwor, </def<span class="note" id="Note8"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">these are translation equivalents</span></span>></p><p><cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">ein<span class="note" id="Note9"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">And this "ein" is weird. It goes for all these three (masculine) nouns, and it actually signals "masculine or neuter" (unless the dictionary uses something extra to mark German neuters)</span></span><span class="note" id="Note10"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">You could assume ellipsis here and the other two two equivalents would actually be "ein Popanz", "ein Unhold" – unfortunately we do not have @expand at hand …</span></span> Schreckbild</quote></cit></p><p><cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">Popanz</quote></cit></p><p><cit type="translation"><quote xml:lang="de">Unhold</quote></cit></p><p><cit type="example"></p><p><span class="gi"><quote></span>Trudno dać wiarę, by to przecie bodło Podnieść cały wóz jedną ręką</p><p>mogło.</quote<span class="note" id="Note11"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">and this quote here consists of two verses. This is signalled by the rhyming "bodło"-"mogło" and by the capitalization of the "Podnieść". I wonder if we can encode this information (it may of course remain implicit).</span></span><span class="note" id="Note12"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">quote/l or even quote/lg/l</span></span>><span class="gi"><bibl></span></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.author" title="<author>"><author></a>Opal.</author> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.title" title="<title>"><title></a>poet.</title> <span class="gi"><biblScope></span>8.</biblScope></bibl></cit></p><p><cit type="example"></p><p><span class="gi"><quote></span>Okrutnym przerażona bodłem. </quote><span class="gi"><bibl></span><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.author" title="<author>"><author></a>Pot.<span class="note" id="Note13"><span class="noteLabel">Note: </span><span class="hi">"Pot." and "Stryjk." are actually abbreviated author names, so we should probably reference the authors listed in the header. Same goes for the titles.</span></span></author> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.title" title="<title>"><title></a>Arg.</title> <span class="gi"><biblScope></span>324.</biblScope></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.author" title="<author>"><author></a>Stryjk.</author> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.title" title="<title>"><title></a>Gon. U.</title> <span class="gi"><biblScope></span>3.</biblScope></bibl></cit></p><p></sense></p><p></entry></p><p><a class="link_ref" href="https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F57EB_zSMPAtDTuAaWC_iRxNQoy4QbjR63t0oWRe4sI/edit?usp=sharing"><span class="hi">https://docs.google.com/document/d/1F57EB_zSMPAtDTuAaWC_iRxNQoy4QbjR63t0oWRe4sI/edit?usp=sharing</span></a></p><ul><li class="item">everywhere where there is a form: use “form”</li><li class="item">cit type=cognate/etymon/descendent for etymology and within: form and @corresp when you want to link to somewhere else</li><li class="item">cit type = equivalent for bilingual dictionaries and within: form and @corresp when you want to link to somewhere else</li><li class="item">unresolved: “a certain plant” in cit type=equivalent</li><li class="item">classical references, eg. see also 1.1, use <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.xr" title="<xr>"><xr></a><span class="gi"><ref></span></li><li class="item">ref is allowed inside of def; examples???</li><li class="item">references in etymology that are a bibl refering to extended description: bibl with @corresp when wanting to link to external source list</li><li class="item">def and gloss: to do: look at examples, from both etymological dictionaries and dictionaries with an etymological section (everyone look for examples)</li></ul><p>Recommendations on how to do encode idioms, collocates, proverbs etc. (Katrien, Toma)</p></div></div>

<span class="element"></entry></span></div></td></tr><tr><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div class="figure"><img src="media/image20.png" alt="" class="inline" style=" width:6.574897222222222cm; height:13.028780555555555cm;"></img></div><p>ارك: ١- أَرَكَ -ُ أُرُكًا الجملُ: اكل ورق الأَرَاكِ ٠ أَرَكَ ٠- أَرَكًا الجملُ اشتكى بطنهُ من أَكل الأَرَاكِ ٠ الأَراك (ن): واحدتهُ أَراكة ج أُرُك و أَرَائِك. شجر ذو شوك. طويل الساق، كثير الورق و الأغصان. خوَّار العود تتَّخذ منه المساويك</p> <p>٢٠ - أَرَكَ ْ -َ أَرَكًا و أَرِكَ ْ -ُ أُركًا الجرحُ: برأَ</p> <p>٣٠ - <span class="hi">أرْوكاريا</span> (ن): شجرة باسقة من فصيلة الصنوبريَّات.منبتها الاصلي٠ اميركا الجنوبية، تزرع في الحدائق للزينة، اوراقها شائكة تنبت حتى على الجذع §</p> <p>٤٠ <span class="hi">-لأَرِكَة</span> ج أَرِيْك و أَرائك: سرير مزيَّن فاخر</p></td><td style="border: 1px solid black; padding: 2px;"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e3287" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><entry <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">root</span>"></span>

  <span class="element"><entry></span>
   <span class="element"><form <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">lemma</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><orth></span>أَرَكَ<span class="element"></orth></span> -ُ أُرُكًا<span class="element"></form></span>

  <span class="element"><div></span>
   <span class="element"><head></span> BACKGROUND:<span class="element"></head></span>
   <span class="element"><p></span>Food insecurity can put children at greater risk of obesity because
       of altered food choices and nonuniform consumption patterns.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"></div></span>
  <span class="element"><div></span>
   <span class="element"><head></span> OBJECTIVE:<span class="element"></head></span>
   <span class="element"><p></span>We examined the association between obesity and both child-level
       food insecurity and personal food insecurity in US children.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"></div></span>
  <span class="element"><div></span>
   <span class="element"><head></span> DESIGN:<span class="element"></head></span>
   <span class="element"><p></span>Data from 9,701 participants in the National Health and Nutrition
       Examination Survey, 2001-2010, aged 2 to 11 years were analyzed.
       Child-level food insecurity was assessed with the US Department of
       Agriculture's Food Security Survey Module based on eight
       child-specific questions. Personal food insecurity was assessed with
       five additional questions. Obesity was defined, using physical
       measurements, as body mass index (calculated as kg/m2) greater than
       or equal to the age- and sex-specific 95th percentile of the Centers
       for Disease Control and Prevention growth charts. Logistic
       regressions adjusted for sex, race/ethnic group, poverty level, and
       survey year were conducted to describe associations between obesity
       and food insecurity.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"></div></span>
  <span class="element"><div></span>
   <span class="element"><head></span> RESULTS:<span class="element"></head></span>
   <span class="element"><p></span>Obesity was significantly associated with personal food insecurity
       for children aged 6 to 11 years (odds ratio=1.81; 95% CI 1.33 to
       2.48), but not in children aged 2 to 5 years (odds ratio=0.88; 95%
       CI 0.51 to 1.51). Child-level food insecurity was not associated
       with obesity among 2- to 5-year-olds or 6- to 11-year-olds.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"></div></span>
  <span class="element"><div></span>
   <span class="element"><head></span> CONCLUSIONS:<span class="element"></head></span>
   <span class="element"><p></span>Personal food insecurity is associated with an increased risk of
       obesity only in children aged 6 to 11 years. Personal
       food-insecurity measures may give different results than aggregate
       food-insecurity measures in children.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"></div></span>
 <span class="element"></div></span>
<span class="element"></front></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Content model</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg cdata">

element is used for headings at all levels; software which treats (e.g.) chapter headings, section headings, and list titles differently must determine the proper processing of a <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.head" title="<head>"><head></a> element based on its structural position. A <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.head" title="<head>"><head></a> occurring as the first element of a list is the title of that list; one occurring as the first element of a <span class="gi"><div1></span> is the title of that chapter or section.</p></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">The most common use for the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.head" title="<head>"><head></a> element is to mark the headings of sections. In older writings, the headings or <span class="term">incipits</span> may be rather longer than usual in modern works. If a section has an explicit ending as well as a heading, it should be marked as a <span class="gi"><trailer></span>, as in this example:<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e16794" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><div1 <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">I</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">book</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><head></span>In the name of Christ here begins the first book of the ecclesiastical history of
   Georgius Florentinus, known as Gregory, Bishop of Tours.<span class="element"></head></span>
 <span class="element"><div2 <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">section</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><head></span>In the name of Christ here begins Book I of the history.<span class="element"></head></span>
  <span class="element"><p></span>Proposing as I do ...<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"><p></span>From the Passion of our Lord until the death of Saint Martin four hundred and twelve
     years passed.<span class="element"></p></span>
  <span class="element"><trailer></span>Here ends the first Book, which covers five thousand, five hundred and ninety-six
     years from the beginning of the world down to the death of Saint Martin.<span class="element"></trailer></span>
 <span class="element"></div2></span>
<span class="element"></div1></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">When headings are not inline with the running text (see e.g. <a class="link_ref" href="http://diglib.hab.de/show_image.php?dir=drucke/ed000364&pointer=34">the heading "Secunda conclusio"</a>) they might however be encoded as if. The actual placement in the source document can be captured with the <span class="att">place</span> attribute.<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e16819" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><div <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">subsection</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><head <span class="attribute">place</span>="<span class="attributevalue">margin</span>"></span>Secunda conclusio<span class="element"></head></span>
 <span class="element"><p></span>
  <span class="element"><lb <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1251</span>"/></span>
  <span class="element"><hi <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">large</span>"></span>Potencia: habitus: et actus: recipiunt speciem ab obiectis<span class="element"><supplied></span>.<span class="element"></supplied></span>
  <span class="element"></hi></span>
  <span class="element"><lb <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1252</span>"/></span>Probatur sic. Omne importans necessariam habitudinem ad proprium
   [...]
 <span class="element"></p></span>
<span class="element"></div></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">The <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.head" title="<head>"><head></a> element is also used to mark headings of other units, such as lists:<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e16840" class="pre egXML_valid">With a few exceptions, connectives are equally
 useful in all kinds of discourse: description, narration, exposition, argument. <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">bulleted</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><head></span>Connectives<span class="element"></head></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>above<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>accordingly<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>across from<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>adjacent to<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>again<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- ... --></span>
 <span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Content model</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg cdata">
<content>
 <alternate minOccurs="0"
  maxOccurs="unbounded">
  <textNode/>
  <elementRef key="lg"/>
  <classRef key="model.gLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.phrase"/>
  <classRef key="model.inter"/>
  <classRef key="model.lLike"/>
  <classRef key="model.global"/>
 </alternate>
</content>
    </pre></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Schema Declaration</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg">

In this usage the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.label" title="<label>"><label></a> element is synonymous with the <span class="att">n</span> attribute on the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.item" title="<item>"><item></a> element:<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e19637" class="pre egXML_valid">I will add two facts, which have seldom occurred
 in the composition of six, or at least of five quartos. <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">runon</span>" <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">ordered</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>(1)<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>My first rough manuscript, without any intermediate copy, has been sent to the press.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>(2) <span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>Not a sheet has been seen by any human eyes, excepting those of the author and the
   printer: the faults and the merits are exclusively my own.<span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">Labels may also be used for other structured list items, as in this extract from the journal of Edward Gibbon:<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e19654" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">gloss</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>March 1757.<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>I wrote some critical observations upon Plautus.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>March 8th.<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>I wrote a long dissertation upon some lines of Virgil.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>June.<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>I saw Mademoiselle Curchod — <span class="element"><quote <span class="attribute">xml:lang</span>="<span class="attributevalue">la</span>"></span>Omnia vincit amor, et nos cedamus
     amori.<span class="element"></quote></span>
 <span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><label></span>August.<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>I went to Crassy, and staid two days.<span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div>Note that the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.label" title="<label>"><label></a> might also appear within the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.item" title="<item>"><item></a> rather than as its sibling. Though syntactically valid, this usage is not recommended TEI practice.</td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">Labels may also be used to represent a label or heading attached to a paragraph or sequence of paragraphs not treated as a structural division, or to a group of verse lines. Note that, in this case, the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.label" title="<label>"><label></a> element appears <em>within</em> the <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.p" title="<p>"><p></a> or <span class="gi"><lg></span> element, rather than as a preceding sibling of it.<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e19699" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><p></span>[...]
<span class="element"><lb/></span>&amp; n’entrer en mauuais &amp; mal-heu-
<span class="element"><lb/></span>ré meſnage. Or des que le conſente-
<span class="element"><lb/></span>ment des parties y eſt le mariage eſt
<span class="element"><lb/></span> arreſté, quoy que de faict il ne ſoit
<span class="element"><label <span class="attribute">place</span>="<span class="attributevalue">margin</span>"></span>Puiſſance maritale
   entre les Romains.<span class="element"></label></span>
 <span class="element"><lb/></span> conſommé. Depuis la conſomma-
<span class="element"><lb/></span>tion du mariage la femme eſt ſoubs
<span class="element"><lb/></span> la puiſſance du mary, s’il n’eſt eſcla-
<span class="element"><lb/></span>ue ou enfant de famille : car en ce
<span class="element"><lb/></span> cas, la femme, qui a eſpouſé vn en-
<span class="element"><lb/></span>fant de famille, eſt ſous la puiſſance
 [...]<span class="element"></p></span></div>In this example the text of the label appears in the right hand margin of the original source, next to the paragraph it describes, but approximately in the middle of it. If so desired the <span class="att">type</span> attribute may be used to distinguish different categories of label.</td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Content model</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg cdata">

egXML_valid"><span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">numbered</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>a butcher<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>a baker<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>a candlestick maker, with
 <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">bulleted</span>"></span>
   <span class="element"><item></span>rings on his fingers<span class="element"></item></span>
   <span class="element"><item></span>bells on his toes<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"></list></span>
 <span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e21938" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">syllogism</span>" <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">bulleted</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>All Cretans are liars.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>Epimenides is a Cretan.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>ERGO Epimenides is a liar.<span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e21951" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">litany</span>" <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">simple</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>God save us from drought.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>God save us from pestilence.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>God save us from wickedness in high places.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"><item></span>Praise be to God.<span class="element"></item></span>
<span class="element"></list></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">The following example treats the short numbered clauses of Anglo-Saxon legal codes as lists of items. The text is from an ordinance of King Athelstan (924–939):<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e21967" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><div1 <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">section</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><head></span>Athelstan's Ordinance<span class="element"></head></span>
 <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">numbered</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1</span>"></span>Concerning thieves. First, that no thief is to be spared who is caught with
     the stolen goods, [if he is] over twelve years and [if the value of the goods is] over
     eightpence.
  <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">numbered</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1.1</span>"></span>And if anyone does spare one, he is to pay for the thief with his
         wergild — and the thief is to be no nearer a settlement on that account — or to
         clear himself by an oath of that amount.<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1.2</span>"></span>If, however, he [the thief] wishes to defend himself or to escape, he is
         not to be spared [whether younger or older than twelve].<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1.3</span>"></span>If a thief is put into prison, he is to be in prison 40 days, and he may
         then be redeemed with 120 shillings; and the kindred are to stand surety for him
         that he will desist for ever.<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1.4</span>"></span>And if he steals after that, they are to pay for him with his wergild,
         or to bring him back there.<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1.5</span>"></span>And if he steals after that, they are to pay for him with his wergild,
         whether to the king or to him to whom it rightly belongs; and everyone of those who
         supported him is to pay 120 shillings to the king as a fine.<span class="element"></item></span>
   <span class="element"></list></span>
  <span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">2</span>"></span>Concerning lordless men. And we pronounced about these lordless men, from whom
     no justice can be obtained, that one should order their kindred to fetch back such a
     person to justice and to find him a lord in public meeting.
  <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">numbered</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">2.1</span>"></span>And if they then will not, or cannot, produce him on that appointed day,
         he is then to be a fugitive afterwards, and he who encounters him is to strike him
         down as a thief.<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">2.2</span>"></span>And he who harbours him after that, is to pay for him with his wergild
         or to clear himself by an oath of that amount.<span class="element"></item></span>
   <span class="element"></list></span>
  <span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">3</span>"></span>Concerning the refusal of justice. The lord who refuses justice and upholds
     his guilty man, so that the king is appealed to, is to repay the value of the goods and
     120 shillings to the king; and he who appeals to the king before he demands justice as
     often as he ought, is to pay the same fine as the other would have done, if he had
     refused him justice.
  <span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">numbered</span>"></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">3.1</span>"></span>And the lord who is an accessory to a theft by his slave, and it becomes
         known about him, is to forfeit the slave and be liable to his wergild on the first
         occasionp if he does it more often, he is to be liable to pay all that he owns.<span class="element"></item></span>
    <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">3.2</span>"></span>And likewise any of the king's treasurers or of our reeves, who has been
         an accessory of thieves who have committed theft, is to liable to the same.<span class="element"></item></span>
   <span class="element"></list></span>
  <span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">4</span>"></span>Concerning treachery to a lord. And we have pronounced concerning treachery to
     a lord, that he [who is accused] is to forfeit his life if he cannot deny it or is
     afterwards convicted at the three-fold ordeal.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"></list></span>
<span class="element"></div1></span></div>Note that nested lists have been used so the tagging mirrors the structure indicated by the two-level numbering of the clauses. The clauses could have been treated as a one-level list with irregular numbering, if desired.</td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Example</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e22008" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><p></span>These decrees, most blessed Pope Hadrian, we propounded in the public council ... and they
 confirmed them in our hand in your stead with the sign of the Holy Cross, and afterwards
 inscribed with a careful pen on the paper of this page, affixing thus the sign of the Holy
 Cross.
<span class="element"><list <span class="attribute">rend</span>="<span class="attributevalue">simple</span>"></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Eanbald, by the grace of God archbishop of the holy church of York, have
     subscribed to the pious and catholic validity of this document with the sign of the Holy
     Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Ælfwold, king of the people across the Humber, consenting have subscribed with
     the sign of the Holy Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Tilberht, prelate of the church of Hexham, rejoicing have subscribed with the
     sign of the Holy Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Higbald, bishop of the church of Lindisfarne, obeying have subscribed with the
     sign of the Holy Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Ethelbert, bishop of Candida Casa, suppliant, have subscribed with thef sign of
     the Holy Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Ealdwulf, bishop of the church of Mayo, have subscribed with devout will.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Æthelwine, bishop, have subscribed through delegates.<span class="element"></item></span>
  <span class="element"><item></span>I, Sicga, patrician, have subscribed with serene mind with the sign of the Holy
     Cross.<span class="element"></item></span>
 <span class="element"></list></span>
<span class="element"></p></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Schematron</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><div class="pre">
<sch:rule context="tei:list[@type='gloss']">
<sch:assert test="tei:label">The content of a "gloss" list should include a sequence of one or more pairs of a label element followed by an item element</sch:assert>
</sch:rule></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Content model</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg cdata">
<content>
 <sequence>
  <alternate minOccurs="0"
   maxOccurs="unbounded">

    maxOccurs="unbounded">

     minOccurs="0"/>
    <sequence minOccurs="1"

     <elementRef key="label"/>
     <classRef key="model.global"
      minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
     <elementRef key="item"/>
     <classRef key="model.global"
      minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>
    </sequence>
   </sequence>

  <sequence minOccurs="0"

    minOccurs="0" maxOccurs="unbounded"/>

</content>
    </pre></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Schema Declaration</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><pre class="pre_eg">

{
   <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.att.global" title="att.global">att.global.attributes</a>,
   <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.att.sortable" title="att.sortable">att.sortable.attributes</a>,

      "gloss" | "index" | "instructions" | "litany" | "syllogism"

   (
      ( <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.model.divTop" title="model.divTop">model.divTop</a> | <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.model.global" title="model.global">model.global</a> )*,
      (
         ( <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.item" title="<item>">item</a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.model.global" title="model.global">model.global</a>* )+
       | (
            headLabel?,
            headItem?,
            ( <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.label" title="<label>">label</a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.model.global" title="model.global">model.global</a>*, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.item" title="<item>">item</a>, <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.model.global" title="model.global">model.global</a>* )+

title="<title>"><title></a> element.</p></td></tr></table></div></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label">level</td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">indicates the bibliographic level for a title, that is, whether it identifies an article, book, journal, series, or unpublished material.</span><div class="table"><table class="attDef"><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Status</span></td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">Optional</span></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Datatype</span></td><td class="odd_value"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.teidata.enumerated" title="teidata.enumerated">teidata.enumerated</a></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Legal values are:</span></td><td class="odd_value"><dl class="valList"><dt><span class="odd_label">a</span></dt><dd>(<span lang="en">analytic</span>) <span lang="en">the title applies to an analytic item, such as an article, poem, or other work published as part of a larger item.</span></dd><dt><span class="odd_label">m</span></dt><dd>(<span lang="en">monographic</span>) <span lang="en">the title applies to a monograph such as a book or other item considered to be a distinct publication, including single volumes of multi-volume works</span></dd><dt><span class="odd_label">j</span></dt><dd>(<span lang="en">journal</span>) <span lang="en">the title applies to any serial or periodical publication such as a journal, magazine, or newspaper</span></dd><dt><span class="odd_label">s</span></dt><dd>(<span lang="en">series</span>) <span lang="en">the title applies to a series of otherwise distinct publications such as a collection</span></dd><dt><span class="odd_label">u</span></dt><dd>(<span lang="en">unpublished</span>) <span lang="en">the title applies to any unpublished material (including theses and dissertations unless published by a commercial press)</span></dd></dl></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>The level of a title is sometimes implied by its context: for example, a title appearing directly within an <span class="gi"><analytic></span> element is <span class="foreign">ipso facto</span> of level <span class="q">‘a’</span>, and one appearing within a <span class="gi"><series></span> element of level <span class="q">‘s’</span>. For this reason, the <span class="att">level</span> attribute is not required in contexts where its value can be unambiguously inferred. Where it is supplied in such contexts, its value should not contradict the value implied by its parent element.</p></td></tr></table></div></td></tr></table></div></td></tr><tr><td Elements Unique to Spoken Texts</a>]</td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Module</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">tei</td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Members</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><span class="showmembers1"><a class="link_odd_elementSpec" href="#TEI.change" title="<change>">change</a></span></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Attributes</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2">Attributes<div class="table"><table class="attList"><tr><td class="odd_label">who</td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">indicates the person, or group of people, to whom the element content is ascribed.</span><div class="table"><table class="attDef"><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Status</span></td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">Optional</span></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Datatype</span></td><td class="odd_value">1–∞ <span lang="en">occurrences of</span> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.teidata.pointer" title="teidata.pointer">teidata.pointer</a> <span lang="en">separated by whitespace</span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2">In the following example from Hamlet, speeches (<span class="gi"><sp></span>) in the body of the play are linked to <span class="gi"><castItem></span> elements in the <span class="gi"><castList></span> using the <span class="att">who</span> attribute.<div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e40762" class="pre egXML_feasible"><span class="element"><castItem <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">role</span>"></span>

<span class="element"></castItem></span>
<span class="element"><castItem <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">role</span>"></span>

 <span class="element"><roleDesc></span>a soldier<span class="element"></roleDesc></span>
<span class="element"></castItem></span>
<span class="comment"><!-- ... --></span>
<span class="element"><sp <span class="attribute">who</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#Barnardo</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><speaker></span>Bernardo<span class="element"></speaker></span>
 <span class="element"><l <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1</span>"></span>Who's there?<span class="element"></l></span>
<span class="element"></sp></span>
<span class="element"><sp <span class="attribute">who</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#Francisco</span>"></span>
 <span class="element"><speaker></span>Francisco<span class="element"></speaker></span>
 <span class="element"><l <span class="attribute">n</span>="<span class="attributevalue">2</span>"></span>Nay, answer me: stand, and unfold yourself.<span class="element"></l></span>
<span class="element"></sp></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>For transcribed speech, this will typically identify a participant or participant group; in other contexts, it will point to any identified <span class="gi"><person></span> element.</p></td></tr></table></div></td></tr></table></div></td></tr></table></div></div><div class="refdoc" id="TEI.att.canonical"><h4><span class="headingNumber">13.3.2. </span><span class="head">att.canonical</span></h4><div class="table"><table class="wovenodd"><tr><td colspan="2" class="wovenodd-col2"><span class="label">att.canonical</span> <span lang="en">provides attributes which can be used to associate a representation such as a name or title with canonical information about the object being named or referenced.</span> [<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/ND.html#NDATTSnr">13.1.1.   <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">organisation</span>"></span>[New Zealand Parliament, Legislative Council]<span class="element"></name></span>

<span class="element"></author></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>The value may be a unique identifier from a database, or any other externally-defined string identifying the referent. </p><p>No particular syntax is proposed for the values of the <span class="att">key</span> attribute, since its form will depend entirely on practice within a given project. In such a situation, a preferable approach for magic tokens which follows standard practice on the Web is to use a <span class="att">ref</span> attribute whose value is a tag URI as defined in RFC 4151.</p></td></tr></table></div></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label">ref</td><td class="odd_value">(<span lang="en">reference</span>) <span lang="en">provides an explicit means of locating a full definition or identity for the entity being named by means of one or more URIs.</span><div class="table"><table class="attDef"><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Status</span></td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">Optional</span></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Datatype</span></td><td class="odd_value">1–∞ <span lang="en">occurrences of</span> <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.teidata.pointer" title="teidata.pointer">teidata.pointer</a> <span lang="en">separated by whitespace</span></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e40962" class="pre egXML_valid"><span class="element"><name <span class="attribute">ref</span>="<span class="attributevalue">http://viaf.org/viaf/109557338</span>"
 <span class="attribute">type</span>="<span class="attributevalue">person</span>"></span>Seamus Heaney<span class="element"></name></span></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>The value must point directly to one or more XML elements or other resources by means of one or more URIs, separated by whitespace.  (<span class="element"><date <span class="attribute">calendar</span>="<span class="attributevalue">#julian</span>"
 <span class="attribute">when</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1732-02-22</span>"></span> Feb. 11, 1731/32, O.S.<span class="element"></date></span>).</div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>Note that the <span class="att">calendar</span> attribute (unlike <span class="att">datingMethod</span> defined in <span class="ident-class">att.datable.custom</span>) defines the calendar system of the date in the original material defined by the parent element, <em>not</em> the calendar to which the date is normalized.</p></td></tr></table></div></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label">period</td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">supplies a pointer to some location defining a named period of time within which the datable item is understood to have occurred.</span><div class="table"><table class="attDef"><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Status</span></td><td class="odd_value"><span lang="en">Optional</span></td></tr><tr><td class="odd_label"><span lang="en" class="label">Datatype</span></td><td class="odd_value"><a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.teidata.pointer" title="teidata.pointer">teidata.pointer</a></td></tr></table></div></td></tr></table></div></td></tr><tr><td class="wovenodd-col1"><span lang="en" class="label">Note</span></td><td class="wovenodd-col2"><p>This ‘superclass’ provides attributes that can be used to provide normalized values of temporal information. By default, the attributes from the <span class="ident-class">att.datable.w3c</span> class are provided. If the module for names & dates is loaded, this class also provides attributes from the <span class="ident-class">att.datable.iso</span> and <span class="ident-class">att.datable.custom</span> classes. In general, the possible values of attributes restricted to the W3C datatypes form a subset of those values available via the ISO 8601 standard. However, the greater expressiveness of the ISO datatypes may not be needed, and there exists much greater software support for the W3C datatypes.</p></td></tr></table></div></div><div class="refdoc" id="TEI.att.datable.w3c"><h4><span class="headingNumber">13.3.4. </span><span class="head">att.datable.w3c</span></h4><div class="table"><table class="wovenodd"><tr><td colspan="2" class="wovenodd-col2"><span class="label">att.datable.w3c</span> <span lang="en">provides attributes for normalization of elements that contain datable events conforming to the W3C <span class="titlem">XML Schema Part 2: Datatypes Second Edition</span>.</span> [<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CO.html#CONADA">3.5.4.  <span class="element"><date <span class="attribute">when</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1945-10-24</span>"></span>24 Oct 45<span class="element"></date></span>
 <span class="element"><date <span class="attribute">when</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1996-09-24T07:25:00Z</span>"></span>September 24th, 1996 at 3:25 in the morning<span class="element"></date></span>
 <span class="element"><time <span class="attribute">when</span>="<span class="attributevalue">1999-01-04T20:42:00-05:00</span>"></span>Jan 4 1999 at 8 pm<span class="element"></time></span>

<span class="element"></p></span></div></td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e41295" class="pre egXML_valid">This list begins in

For the time part, the form <code>hh:mm:ss</code> is used.</p><p>Note that this format does not currently permit use of the value <span class="val">0000</span> to represent the year 1 BCE; instead the value <span class="val">-0001</span> should be used.</p></td></tr></table></div></div><div class="refdoc" id="TEI.att.datcat"><h4><span class="headingNumber">13.3.5. </span><span class="head">att.datcat</span></h4><div class="table"><table class="wovenodd"><tr><td colspan="2" class="wovenodd-col2"><span class="label">att.datcat</span> <span lang="en">provides the <span class="att">dcr:datacat</span> and <span class="att">dcr:ValueDatacat</span> attributes which are used to align XML elements or attributes with the appropriate Data Categories (DCs) defined by the ISO 12620:2009 standard and stored in the Web repository called ISOCat at <a class="link_ref" href="http://www.isocat.org/">http://www.isocat.org/</a>.</span> [<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/DI.html#DIMVLV">9.5.2. Data categories are defined as elementary descriptors in a linguistic structure. In the DCR data model each data category gets assigned a unique Peristent IDentifier (PID), i.e., an URI. Linguistic resources or preferably their schemas that make use of data categories from a DCR should refer to them using this PID. For XML-based resources, like TEI documents, ISO 12620:2009 normative Annex A gives a small Data Category Reference XML vocabulary (also available online at <a class="link_ref" href="http://www.isocat.org/12620/">http://www.isocat.org/12620/</a>), which provides two attributes, <span class="att">dcr:datcat</span> and <span class="att">dcr:valueDatcat</span>.</p></td></tr></table></div></div><div class="refdoc" id="TEI.att.declarable"><h4><span class="headingNumber">13.3.6. </span><span class="head">att.declarable</span></h4><div class="table"><table class="wovenodd"><tr><td colspan="2" class="wovenodd-col2"><span class="label">att.declarable</span> <span lang="en">provides attributes for those elements in the TEI header which may be independently selected by means of the special purpose <span class="att">decls</span> attribute.</span> [<a class="link_ref" href="http://www.tei-c.org/release/doc/tei-p5-doc/en/html/CC.html#CCAS">15.3. <span class="element"></group></span></div>In this example a <span class="gi"><group></span> contains two <a class="link_ref" href="#TEI.text" title="<text>"><text></a>s, each containing the same document in a different language. The correspondence is indicated using <span class="att">corresp</span>. The language is indicated using <span class="att">xml:lang</span>, whose value is inherited; both the tag with the <span class="att">corresp</span> and the tag pointed to by the <span class="att">corresp</span> inherit the value from their immediate parent.</td></tr><tr><td colspan="2"><div id="index.xml-egXML-d29e44748" class="pre egXML_valid">

<span class="element"></person></span>

 <span class="element"><note></span>
  <span class="element"><p></span>Personification of London’s genius. Appears as an
